org.jtrim.event

Class InitLaterListenerRef

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jtrim.event.InitLaterListenerRef
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ListenerRef

    public final class InitLaterListenerRef
extends java.lang.Object
implements ListenerRef
    Defines a ListenerRef forwarding its calls to another ListenerRef which is specified after construction time. This class is useful if you need to unregister a listener in the listener itself (or in any code which is defined before actually registering the listener).

    This is the recommended usage pattern: 

     ListenerRegistry<Runnable> registry = ...;

 final InitLaterListenerRef listenerRef = new InitLaterListenerRef();
 // From this point, you may use "listenerRef" to unregister the listener.
 // The listener will be unregistered as soon as the "init" method has been
 // called

 listenerRef.init(registry.registerListener(new Runnable(){
   // You may use "listenerRef" here to unregister this listener.
 }));

    Note that the actual unregistering of the listener will not happen until you call the init(ListenerRef) method. Therefore, if you unregister the listener prior calling init, it may be possible, that the listener will be notified even if you have called unregister() on the InitLaterListenerRef which is a violation of the contract of the ListenerRef interface. Therefore, it is not recommended not unregister the listener before calling the init method. If you do unregister it, don't forget that it is possible that you may receive event notifications.

    Thread safety

    Methods of this class are safe to use by multiple threads concurrently.

    Synchronization transparency

    Methods of this class are synchronization transparent, assuming that the underlying listener is synchronization transparent.

    • Constructor Detail

      • InitLaterListenerRef

        public InitLaterListenerRef()
        Creates a new InitLaterListenerRef with no underlying ListenerRef. Call the init method, to set the ListenerRef to which calls are to be forwarded.

    • Method Detail

      • init

        public void init(ListenerRef listenerRef)
        Sets to ListenerRef to which calls are forwarded to. This method may not be called more than once.

        If unregister() has been called on this InitLaterListenerRef, this method will call the unregister() method of the passed ListenerRef.

        Note that before calling this method, isRegistered() will return true.

        Parameters:
        listenerRef - the ListenerRef to which class are forwarded to. This argument cannot be null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - thrown if this method has already been called

      • isRegistered

        public boolean isRegistered()
        Checks whether the listener is currently registered to receive notifications of events.

        In case this method returns true, the method unregister() can be called to stop the listener from receiving notifications of the events occurring. If this method returns false, the unregister() method has no useful effect and listener notifications can be expected to stop at some time in the future. Note that even if this method returns false, some pending event notifications might be forwarded..

        Implementation note: This method will always return true prior calling the init method.

        Specified by:
        isRegistered in interface ListenerRef
        Returns:
        true if the listener is currently registered to be notified of occurring events, false if the listener was unregistered, so calling unregister is no longer necessary

      • unregister

        public void unregister()
        Unregisters the listener, so it does not need to be notified of subsequent events. Calling this method ensures that there will be a point in time in the future from when notifications of new events will no longer be forwarded. That is, it is possible that some subsequent events will still be forwarded to the associated listener but forwarding of these events will eventually stop without further interaction.

        This method must be idempotent. That is, invoking it multiple times has the same effect as invoking it only once.

        Implementation note: If you call this method before calling the init method, this method will simply cause the subsequent init method to unregister the underlying ListenerRef.

        This method is allowed to be called concurrently with the init method.

        Specified by:
        unregister in interface ListenerRef
